title: HORRIBILE DICTU* in mind, so bold and precise is its juxtaposition of contradictory ideas. In a recruitment leaflet for a pressure group, a supporter is quoted as saying: “Friends of the Earth are doing things I can believe in—incredible things.”
html:
HORRIBILE DICTU* in mind, so bold and precise is its juxtaposition of contradictory ideas. In a recruitment leaflet for a pressure group, a supporter is quoted as saying: “Friends of the Earth are doing things I can believe in—incredible things.”

An instalment of this column wouldn't be the same without some egregious gibberish (in inverted commas, I mean). When an accountant employed by the commission of the European Union engaged in an act of whistleblowing—warning that the EU's accounting systems were open to fraud and error—a commission spokesman said “We will be putting her in another function, to put it mildly.” If he'd put it bluntly, it turns out, he would have said “She's been fired.”
